natural problem: A play has two different male roles, two different female roles and two different roles that can be either gender. Only a man can be assigned to a male role, and only a woman can be assigned to a female role. If five men and six women audition, in how many ways can the six roles be assigned?
natural solution: We start with the most restrictive conditions: the roles that are not open to both men and women. First, we will fill the two male roles. There are 5 men, so there are $5 \cdot 4= 20$ ways to assign 2 of the 5 men to the distinct male roles.

Doing the same for the female roles, there are $6 \cdot 5 = 30$ ways. Finally, of the $5+6 - 2 - 2 = 7$ remaining actors, there are $7 \cdot 6 = 42$ ways to assign the leftovers to the either-gender roles.
Multiplying, there are $20 \cdot 30 \cdot 42 = \boxed{25200}$ ways of assigning the six roles.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes men women roles :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
and h2 : "roles = 6"
shows  "n_permutations men women roles = 25200"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A play has two different male roles, two different female roles and two different roles that can be either gender. Only a man can be assigned to a male role, and only a woman can be assigned to a female role. If five men and six women audition, in how many ways can the six roles be assigned? The final Answer is 25200
 ### Proof
 We start with the most restrictive conditions: the roles that are not open to both men and women. First, we will fill the two male roles. There are 5 men, so there are $5 \cdot 4= 20$ ways to assign 2 of the 5 men to the distinct male roles.
 Doing the same for the female roles, there are $6 \cdot 5 = 30$ ways. Finally, of the $5+6 - 2 - 2 = 7$ remaining actors, there are $7 \cdot 6 = 42$ ways to assign the leftovers to the either-gender roles.
 Multiplying, there are $20 \cdot 30 \cdot 42 = \boxed{25200}$ ways of assigning the six roles.
 *)

theorem
fixes men women roles :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
and h2 : "roles = 6"
shows  "n_permutations men women roles = 25200"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a play, there are 5 men and 6 women. There are 6 roles available to be filled by these actors. How many different ways can the roles be filled? The final answer is 25,200.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes audition_men audition_women :: nat and male_roles female_roles general_roles :: nat
assumes h0 : "audition_men = 5"
and h1 : "audition_women = 6"
and h2 : "male_roles = 2"
and h3 : "female_roles = 2"
and h4 : "general_roles = 2"
shows  "n_permutations audition_men male_roles * n_permutations audition_women female_roles * n_permutations (audition_men + audition_women - male_roles - female_roles) general_roles = 25200"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A play has two different male roles, two different female roles and two different roles that can be either gender. Only a man can be assigned to a male role, and only a woman can be assigned to a female role. If five men and six women audition, in how many ways can the six roles be assigned? The final Answer is 25200
 ### Proof
 We start with the most restrictive conditions: the roles that are not open to both men and women. First, we will fill the two male roles. There are 5 men, so there are $5 \cdot 4= 20$ ways to assign 2 of the 5 men to the distinct male roles.
 Doing the same for the female roles, there are $6 \cdot 5 = 30$ ways. Finally, of the $5+6 - 2 - 2 = 7$ remaining actors, there are $7 \cdot 6 = 42$ ways to assign the leftovers to the either-gender roles.
 Multiplying, there are $20 \cdot 30 \cdot 42 = \boxed{25200}$ ways of assigning the six roles.
 *)

theorem
fixes audition_men audition_women :: nat and male_roles female_roles general_roles :: nat
assumes h0 : "audition_men = 5"
and h1 : "audition_women = 6"
and h2 : "male_roles = 2"
and h3 : "female_roles = 2"
and h4 : "general_roles = 2"
shows  "n_permutations audition_men male_roles * n_permutations audition_women female_roles * n_permutations (audition_men + audition_women - male_roles - female_roles) general_roles = 25200"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a theater audition, there are 5 men and 6 women. There are 2 male roles, 2 female roles, and 2 general roles that can be played by either a man or a woman. How many different ways can the roles be assigned to the auditionees? The final answer is 25,200.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes men women :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
shows  "n_choose_k men 2 * n_choose_k women 2 * n_choose_k (men + women) 2 = 25200"
  where "n_choose_k n k = (fact n) div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
  and fact_def: "fact n = (if n = 0 then 1 else n * fact (n - 1))"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A play has two different male roles, two different female roles and two different roles that can be either gender. Only a man can be assigned to a male role, and only a woman can be assigned to a female role. If five men and six women audition, in how many ways can the six roles be assigned? The final Answer is 25200
 ### Proof
 We start with the most restrictive conditions: the roles that are not open to both men and women. First, we will fill the two male roles. There are 5 men, so there are $5 \cdot 4= 20$ ways to assign 2 of the 5 men to the distinct male roles.
 Doing the same for the female roles, there are $6 \cdot 5 = 30$ ways. Finally, of the $5+6 - 2 - 2 = 7$ remaining actors, there are $7 \cdot 6 = 42$ ways to assign the leftovers to the either-gender roles.
 Multiplying, there are $20 \cdot 30 \cdot 42 = \boxed{25200}$ ways of assigning the six roles.
 *)

theorem
fixes men women :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
shows  "n_choose_k men 2 * n_choose_k women 2 * n_choose_k (men + women) 2 = 25200"
  where "n_choose_k n k = (fact n) div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
  and fact_def: "fact n = (if n = 0 then 1 else n * fact (n - 1))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a group of 5 men and 6 women, how many ways can you choose 2 men, 2 women, and then 2 people from the entire group? The final answer is 25,200.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes men women total_roles :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
and h2 : "total_roles = 6"
shows  "card {(m1, m2, f1, f2, r1, r2) | m1 m2 f1 f2 r1 r2. m1 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m2 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2
    \<and> f1 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f2 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f1 \<noteq> f2
    \<and> r1 \<in> {1..men+women} \<and> r2 \<in> {1..men+women} \<and> r1 \<noteq> r2 \<and> r1 \<noteq> m1 \<and> r1 \<noteq> m2 \<and> r1 \<noteq> f1 \<and> r1 \<noteq> f2
    \<and> r2 \<noteq> m1 \<and> r2 \<noteq> m2 \<and> r2 \<noteq> f1 \<and> r2 \<noteq> f2} = 25200"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A play has two different male roles, two different female roles and two different roles that can be either gender. Only a man can be assigned to a male role, and only a woman can be assigned to a female role. If five men and six women audition, in how many ways can the six roles be assigned? The final Answer is 25200
 ### Proof
 We start with the most restrictive conditions: the roles that are not open to both men and women. First, we will fill the two male roles. There are 5 men, so there are $5 \cdot 4= 20$ ways to assign 2 of the 5 men to the distinct male roles.
 Doing the same for the female roles, there are $6 \cdot 5 = 30$ ways. Finally, of the $5+6 - 2 - 2 = 7$ remaining actors, there are $7 \cdot 6 = 42$ ways to assign the leftovers to the either-gender roles.
 Multiplying, there are $20 \cdot 30 \cdot 42 = \boxed{25200}$ ways of assigning the six roles.
 *)

theorem
fixes men women total_roles :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
and h2 : "total_roles = 6"
shows  "card {(m1, m2, f1, f2, r1, r2) | m1 m2 f1 f2 r1 r2. m1 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m2 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2
    \<and> f1 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f2 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f1 \<noteq> f2
    \<and> r1 \<in> {1..men+women} \<and> r2 \<in> {1..men+women} \<and> r1 \<noteq> r2 \<and> r1 \<noteq> m1 \<and> r1 \<noteq> m2 \<and> r1 \<noteq> f1 \<and> r1 \<noteq> f2
    \<and> r2 \<noteq> m1 \<and> r2 \<noteq> m2 \<and> r2 \<noteq> f1 \<and> r2 \<noteq> f2} = 25200"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a group of 5 men and 6 women, how many ways can you select two men, two women, and two additional roles (neither of which can be the same as the selected men or women) from the group? The final answer is 25,200.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes audition_males audition_females :: nat
assumes h0 : "audition_males = 5"
and h1 : "audition_females = 6"
shows  "card {assignments :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat). assign_roles audition_males audition_females assignments} = 25200"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A play has two different male roles, two different female roles and two different roles that can be either gender. Only a man can be assigned to a male role, and only a woman can be assigned to a female role. If five men and six women audition, in how many ways can the six roles be assigned? The final Answer is 25200
 ### Proof

 Doing the same for the female roles, there are $6 \cdot 5 = 30$ ways. Finally, of the $5+6 - 2 - 2 = 7$ remaining actors, there are $7 \cdot 6 = 42$ ways to assign the leftovers to the either-gender roles.
 Multiplying, there are $20 \cdot 30 \cdot 42 = \boxed{25200}$ ways of assigning the six roles.
 *)

theorem
fixes audition_males audition_females :: nat
assumes h0 : "audition_males = 5"
and h1 : "audition_females = 6"
shows  "card {assignments :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat). assign_roles audition_males audition_females assignments} = 25200"

a_4.informal problem: In a theater audition, there are 5 male roles and 6 female roles. How many different ways can the roles be assigned to the auditionees? The final answer is 25,200.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes men women total_roles :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
and h2 : "total_roles = 2 + 2 + 2"
shows  "n_subsets men 2 * n_subsets women 2 * n_subsets (men + women - 4) 2 = 25200"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A play has two different male roles, two different female roles and two different roles that can be either gender. Only a man can be assigned to a male role, and only a woman can be assigned to a female role. If five men and six women audition, in how many ways can the six roles be assigned? The final Answer is 25200
 ### Proof
 We start with the most restrictive conditions: the roles that are not open to both men and women. First, we will fill the two male roles. There are 5 men, so there are $5 \cdot 4= 20$ ways to assign 2 of the 5 men to the distinct male roles.
 Doing the same for the female roles, there are $6 \cdot 5 = 30$ ways. Finally, of the $5+6 - 2 - 2 = 7$ remaining actors, there are $7 \cdot 6 = 42$ ways to assign the leftovers to the either-gender roles.
 Multiplying, there are $20 \cdot 30 \cdot 42 = \boxed{25200}$ ways of assigning the six roles.
 *)

theorem
fixes men women total_roles :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
and h2 : "total_roles = 2 + 2 + 2"
shows  "n_subsets men 2 * n_subsets women 2 * n_subsets (men + women - 4) 2 = 25200"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: There are 5 men and 6 women auditioning for a play with 6 roles, divided into 3 pairs of roles. In how many ways can the director assign each pair of roles to a man and a woman, so that no person is assigned more than one role? The final answer is 25,200.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_ways = (5 choose 2) * (6 choose 2) * (7 choose 2)"
shows  "num_ways = 25200"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A play has two different male roles, two different female roles and two different roles that can be either gender. Only a man can be assigned to a male role, and only a woman can be assigned to a female role. If five men and six women audition, in how many ways can the six roles be assigned? The final Answer is 25200
 ### Proof
 We start with the most restrictive conditions: the roles that are not open to both men and women. First, we will fill the two male roles. There are 5 men, so there are $5 \cdot 4= 20$ ways to assign 2 of the 5 men to the distinct male roles.
 Doing the same for the female roles, there are $6 \cdot 5 = 30$ ways. Finally, of the $5+6 - 2 - 2 = 7$ remaining actors, there are $7 \cdot 6 = 42$ ways to assign the leftovers to the either-gender roles.
 Multiplying, there are $20 \cdot 30 \cdot 42 = \boxed{25200}$ ways of assigning the six roles.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_ways = (5 choose 2) * (6 choose 2) * (7 choose 2)"
shows  "num_ways = 25200"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In how many ways can you choose 2 elements from each of the three sets: a set of 5 elements, a set of 6 elements, and a set of 7 elements? The final answer is 25,200.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes men women :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
shows  "card {((m1, m2), (f1, f2), (e1, e2)) | m1 m2 f1 f2 e1 e2. m1 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m2 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2 \<and> f1 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f2 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f1 \<noteq> f2 \<and> e1 \<in> {1..men} \<union> {1..women} \<and> e2 \<in> {1..men} \<union> {1..women} \<and> e1 \<noteq> e2 \<and> e1 \<noteq> m1 \<and> e1 \<noteq> m2 \<and> e1 \<noteq> f1 \<and> e1 \<noteq> f2 \<and> e2 \<noteq> m1 \<and> e2 \<noteq> m2 \<and> e2 \<noteq> f1 \<and> e2 \<noteq> f2} = 25200"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A play has two different male roles, two different female roles and two different roles that can be either gender. Only a man can be assigned to a male role, and only a woman can be assigned to a female role. If five men and six women audition, in how many ways can the six roles be assigned? The final Answer is 25200
 ### Proof
 We start with the most restrictive conditions: the roles that are not open to both men and women. First, we will fill the two male roles. There are 5 men, so there are $5 \cdot 4= 20$ ways to assign 2 of the 5 men to the distinct male roles.
 Doing the same for the female roles, there are $6 \cdot 5 = 30$ ways. Finally, of the $5+6 - 2 - 2 = 7$ remaining actors, there are $7 \cdot 6 = 42$ ways to assign the leftovers to the either-gender roles.
 Multiplying, there are $20 \cdot 30 \cdot 42 = \boxed{25200}$ ways of assigning the six roles.
 *)

theorem
fixes men women :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
shows  "card {((m1, m2), (f1, f2), (e1, e2)) | m1 m2 f1 f2 e1 e2. m1 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m2 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2 \<and> f1 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f2 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f1 \<noteq> f2 \<and> e1 \<in> {1..men} \<union> {1..women} \<and> e2 \<in> {1..men} \<union> {1..women} \<and> e1 \<noteq> e2 \<and> e1 \<noteq> m1 \<and> e1 \<noteq> m2 \<and> e1 \<noteq> f1 \<and> e1 \<noteq> f2 \<and> e2 \<noteq> m1 \<and> e2 \<noteq> m2 \<and> e2 \<noteq> f1 \<and> e2 \<noteq> f2} = 25200"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a group, there are 5 men and 6 women. How many different ways can you choose 2 men, 2 women, and 2 extra people (not necessarily of different genders) from the group, such that no person is chosen twice? The final answer is 25,200 ways.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes numberOfWays :: nat
assumes h0 : "numberOfWays = (\<Sum> m1 \<in> {1..5}. \<Sum> m2 \<in> {1..5} - {m1}. \<Sum> f1 \<in> {1..6}. \<Sum> f2 \<in> {1..6} - {f1}. 
                      (\<Sum> e1 \<in> {1..5} - {m1, m2} \<union> {1..6} - {f1, f2}. \<Sum> e2 \<in> {1..5} - {m1, m2} \<union> {1..6} - {f1, f2} - {e1}. 1))"
shows  "numberOfWays = 25200"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A play has two different male roles, two different female roles and two different roles that can be either gender. Only a man can be assigned to a male role, and only a woman can be assigned to a female role. If five men and six women audition, in how many ways can the six roles be assigned? The final Answer is 25200
 ### Proof
 We start with the most restrictive conditions: the roles that are not open to both men and women. First, we will fill the two male roles. There are 5 men, so there are $5 \cdot 4= 20$ ways to assign 2 of the 5 men to the distinct male roles.
 Doing the same for the female roles, there are $6 \cdot 5 = 30$ ways. Finally, of the $5+6 - 2 - 2 = 7$ remaining actors, there are $7 \cdot 6 = 42$ ways to assign the leftovers to the either-gender roles.
 Multiplying, there are $20 \cdot 30 \cdot 42 = \boxed{25200}$ ways of assigning the six roles.
 *)

theorem
fixes numberOfWays :: nat
assumes h0 : "numberOfWays = (\<Sum> m1 \<in> {1..5}. \<Sum> m2 \<in> {1..5} - {m1}. \<Sum> f1 \<in> {1..6}. \<Sum> f2 \<in> {1..6} - {f1}. 
                      (\<Sum> e1 \<in> {1..5} - {m1, m2} \<union> {1..6} - {f1, f2}. \<Sum> e2 \<in> {1..5} - {m1, m2} \<union> {1..6} - {f1, f2} - {e1}. 1))"
shows  "numberOfWays = 25200"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a game, there are 5 men (m1, m2, m3, m4, m5) and 6 women (f1, f2, f3, f4, f5, f6). Find the number of ways to form a committee of 7 members consisting of 2 men, 2 women, and 3 other members who can be either men or women. The final answer is 25,200.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes men women :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
shows  "card {(m1, m2, f1, f2, e1, e2). m1 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m2 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2 \<and>
                                 f1 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f2 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f1 \<noteq> f2 \<and>
                                 e1 \<in> ({1..men} \<union> {1..women}) \<and> e2 \<in> ({1..men} \<union> {1..women}) \<and>
                                 e1 \<noteq> e2 \<and> e1 \<noteq> m1 \<and> e1 \<noteq> m2 \<and> e1 \<noteq> f1 \<and> e1 \<noteq> f2 \<and>
                                 e2 \<noteq> m1 \<and> e2 \<noteq> m2 \<and> e2 \<noteq> f1 \<and> e2 \<noteq> f2} = 25200"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A play has two different male roles, two different female roles and two different roles that can be either gender. Only a man can be assigned to a male role, and only a woman can be assigned to a female role. If five men and six women audition, in how many ways can the six roles be assigned? The final Answer is 25200
 ### Proof
 We start with the most restrictive conditions: the roles that are not open to both men and women. First, we will fill the two male roles. There are 5 men, so there are $5 \cdot 4= 20$ ways to assign 2 of the 5 men to the distinct male roles.
 Doing the same for the female roles, there are $6 \cdot 5 = 30$ ways. Finally, of the $5+6 - 2 - 2 = 7$ remaining actors, there are $7 \cdot 6 = 42$ ways to assign the leftovers to the either-gender roles.
 Multiplying, there are $20 \cdot 30 \cdot 42 = \boxed{25200}$ ways of assigning the six roles.
 *)

theorem
fixes men women :: nat
assumes h0 : "men = 5"
and h1 : "women = 6"
shows  "card {(m1, m2, f1, f2, e1, e2). m1 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m2 \<in> {1..men} \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2 \<and>
                                 f1 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f2 \<in> {1..women} \<and> f1 \<noteq> f2 \<and>
                                 e1 \<in> ({1..men} \<union> {1..women}) \<and> e2 \<in> ({1..men} \<union> {1..women}) \<and>
                                 e1 \<noteq> e2 \<and> e1 \<noteq> m1 \<and> e1 \<noteq> m2 \<and> e1 \<noteq> f1 \<and> e1 \<noteq> f2 \<and>
                                 e2 \<noteq> m1 \<and> e2 \<noteq> m2 \<and> e2 \<noteq> f1 \<and> e2 \<noteq> f2} = 25200"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a group of 5 men and 6 women, how many ways can you choose two distinct men (m1 and m2), two distinct women (f1 and f2), and two other distinct people (e1 and e2) from the group such that e1 and e2 are not any of the previously chosen men or women? The final answer is 25,200.
